(symmetry code i: 1−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; ii: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1/2−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1/2+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; iii: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1/2−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −1/2+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>).</ce:simple-para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0015" view="all">A novel heterometallic 2D coordination polymer, {[Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(CuL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L=<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-2-hydroxyacetophenoneglycylglycine), was synthesized by self-assembly between metalloligands [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the Ba(II) ions. The structure reveals the polymer contains hexanuclear building blocks, which are connected to form 28-membered decanuclear metallocycles, and are assembled further into 2D network structure.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel heterometallic 2D coordination polymer, {[Ba(H2O)4(CuL)2]}∞ (1) (H3L=N-2-hydroxyacetophenoneglycylglycine), was synthesized by self-assembly between metalloligands [CuL]- and the Ba(II) ions. The structure reveals the polymer contains hexanuclear building blocks, which are connected to form 28-membered decanuclear metallocycles, and are assembled further into 2D network structure.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="para0005" view="all">The design of metal-containing building blocks to spontaneously assembly into higher order architectures is of considerable interest in relation to their intriguing diverse architectures, their resemblance to biopolymers as well as their potential applications in catalysis and advanced materials such as magnetic, optic and electronic materials . Some stable coordination compounds containing potential bridging blocks have been used as “metalloligand” to bind other metal ions to form multi-dimensional architectures . Recently, in the course of our project to design and assemble transition-alkali earth heterometallic complexes, we synthesized Cu(II) dipeptide Schiff-base complex [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L=<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-2-hydroxyacetophenoneglycylglycine). The main feature of the complex can be described as follows: (1) the deprotonated Schiff-base ligand act in quadridentate ONNO chelate mode in coordination to Cu(II) center, forming one type of rigid structure; (2) due to containing multifunctional coordination groups (carbonyl and carboxylate oxygen), the Schiff-base complex could be used as potential metalloligand to bind other metal ions designing carboxylate-bridged heterometallic polynuclear complexes and constructing a variety of extended multi-dimensional heterometallic supramolecular coordination polymers; (3) it has a strong capability of forming hydrogen bonding that plays an important role in the assembly of supramolecular compounds. On the other hand, until now, the study on the coordination polymers overwhelmingly focuses on the transition metals and the understanding of the chemistry of carboxylate-bridged heterometallic polynuclear compounds, especially for the heteronuclear polymers containing transition metals and main group metals, is very limited . Herein, we reported a novel heterometallic coordination polymer with a 2D network structure of general formula [Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(CuL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] by the self-assembly of metalloligands [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the Ba(II) ions in aqueous solution. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first heterometallic coordination network structure containing dipeptide Schiff-base complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of metal-containing building blocks to spontaneously assembly into higher order architectures is of considerable interest in relation to their intriguing diverse architectures, their resemblance to biopolymers as well as their potential applications in catalysis and advanced materials such as magnetic, optic and electronic materials . Some stable coordination compounds containing potential bridging blocks have been used as "metalloligand" to bind other metal ions to form multi-dimensional architectures . Recently, in the course of our project to design and assemble transition-alkali earth heterometallic complexes, we synthesized Cu(II) dipeptide Schiff-base complex [CuL]- (H3L=N-2-hydroxyacetophenoneglycylglycine). The main feature of the complex can be described as follows: (1) the deprotonated Schiff-base ligand act in quadridentate ONNO chelate mode in coordination to Cu(II) center, forming one type of rigid structure; (2) due to containing multifunctional coordination groups (carbonyl and carboxylate oxygen), the Schiff-base complex could be used as potential metalloligand to bind other metal ions designing carboxylate-bridged heterometallic polynuclear complexes and constructing a variety of extended multi-dimensional heterometallic supramolecular coordination polymers; (3) it has a strong capability of forming hydrogen bonding that plays an important role in the assembly of supramolecular compounds. On the other hand, until now, the study on the coordination polymers overwhelmingly focuses on the transition metals and the understanding of the chemistry of carboxylate-bridged heterometallic polynuclear compounds, especially for the heteronuclear polymers containing transition metals and main group metals, is very limited . Herein, we reported a novel heterometallic coordination polymer with a 2D network structure of general formula [Ba(H2O)4(CuL)2] by the self-assembly of metalloligands [CuL]- and the Ba(II) ions in aqueous solution. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first heterometallic coordination network structure containing dipeptide Schiff-base complex.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0010" view="all">Glycylglycine (10 mmol), 2-hydroxyacetophenone (10 mmol) and KOH (10 mmol) were dissolved and refluxed in MeOH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (v:v=1:1) for half an hour. Cu(OAC)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10 mmol) was then added to the solution and the resulting solution was adjusted to the pH 9–10. At last BaCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5 mmol) was added. The violet precipitate was obtained, which can be recrystallized from hot water (90 °C). The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature. After several days violet red crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction, were obtained.<ce:footnote id="FN2">
<ce:label>2</ce:label>
<ce:note-para>
<ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ba: C, 34.69; H, 3.61; N, 6.74%. IR (KBr; cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3442s, 1655s, 1609s, 1340m, 1297m. ESI-MS (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>): 310.1, [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. Yield, 75%. Found: C, 34.58; H, 3.61; N, 6.66%.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>

</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Glycylglycine (10 mmol), 2-hydroxyacetophenone (10 mmol) and KOH (10 mmol) were dissolved and refluxed in MeOH/H2O (v:v=1:1) for half an hour. Cu(OAC)⋅H2O (10 mmol) was then added to the solution and the resulting solution was adjusted to the pH 9-10. At last BaCl2 ⋅2H2O (5 mmol) was added. The violet precipitate was obtained, which can be recrystallized from hot water (90 °C). The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature. After several days violet red crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction, were obtained. 2  Anal. Calc. for C24H30N4O12 Cu2Ba: C, 34.69; H, 3.61; N, 6.74%. IR (KBr; cm-1): 3442s, 1655s, 1609s, 1340m, 1297m. ESI-MS (m/z): 310.1, [CuL]-. Yield, 75%. Found: C, 34.58; H, 3.61; N, 6.66%.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0015" view="all">The building block unit of the extended structure is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>.<ce:footnote id="FN3">
<ce:label>3</ce:label>
<ce:note-para>Crystallographic data of [Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(CuL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] are: C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ba, <ce:italic>Fw</ce:italic>=830.95, monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=21.532(4) Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=7.266(1) Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=18.353(3) Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=91.57(1)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>=2870.3(8) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4, <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>=1.923 gcm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, crystals size: 0.15×0.15×0.20 mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, 13627 reflections collected, of which 5018 (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">int</ce:inf>=0.0587 [<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>>2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>)]) were used in the refinement to give final <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>=0.0321 and <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=0.0618. Intensity data were collected on a Bruker CCD X-ray diffractomter using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using a SHELXTL software package.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>
 The coordination environment of the Cu(II) centers is approximately square-planar. The Schiff-base ligand is deprotonated, thus acting as a triple negatively charged quadridentate ONNO chelate. It coordinated to the Cu(II) atom via one phenolic oxygen (O(1)), one deprotonated amide nitrogen atom (N(2)), one imino nitrogen atom (N(1)) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O(3)). The best-fit least-squares plane through the four basal and Cu atoms shows these atoms to be nearly coplanar. The O(1)–Cu(1)–N(2) angle of 179.39(15)° is nearly linear. The phenyl ring [C(1)–C(6)] and the ring of C(1), C(6), C(7), N(1), O(1), Cu(1) chelate ring are almost coplanar with a small dihedral angle of 5.5°. The coordination environment of Cu(2) is similar to that of Cu(1). The coordination of Cu and L forms a rigid metalloligand [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> to bind Ba(II) ions. Ba(II) ion is ten-coordinated to five carboxylate oxygen (O(3), O(4), O(7), O(8), O(4)i; symmetry code i: 1−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>), one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)ii; symmetry code ii: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1/2−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1/2+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) and four aqua ligands (O(1w), O(2w), O(3w), O(4w)). The Ba–O (water) distances range from 2.751(3) to 2.843(3) Å. The Ba–O (carboxylic and carbonyl oxygen) distances ranging from 2.758(3) to 3.059(3) Å are similar to the reported values . Two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and [Cu(2)L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) coordinate to Ba(II) by two different modes: [Cu(1)L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> coordinate to Ba(II) ion through two bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms (O(3), O(4)) in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging manner. The Ba(1) and Cu(1) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(3) with Ba–Cu distance 4.65 Å, and Ba(1) and Ba(1A) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(4) and O(4A) and the Ba–Ba distance is 4.86 Å. [Cu(2)L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> coordinates to Ba(II) ions through two carboxylate oxygen (O(7), O(8)) in a bidentate manner and one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)). The dihedral angle between chelate ring planes of the two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and [Cu(2)L]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) is 29.2°. The nearest Cu⋯Cu distance is 3.56 Å between the two planes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The building block unit of the extended structure is shown in  . 3 Crystallographic data of [Ba(H2O)4(CuL)2] are: C24H30N4O12Cu2Ba, Fw=830.95, monoclinic, space group P21 c, a=21.532(4) Å, b=7.266(1) Å, c=18.353(3) Å, β=91.57(1)°, V=2870.3(8) Å3, Z=4, D calc=1.923 gcm-3, crystals size: 0.15×0.15×0.20 mm3, 13627 reflections collected, of which 5018 (R int=0.0587 [I>2σ(I)]) were used in the refinement to give final R 1=0.0321 and wR 2=0.0618. Intensity data were collected on a Bruker CCD X-ray diffractomter using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method against F 2 using a SHELXTL software package.   The coordination environment of the Cu(II) centers is approximately square-planar. The Schiff-base ligand is deprotonated, thus acting as a triple negatively charged quadridentate ONNO chelate. It coordinated to the Cu(II) atom via one phenolic oxygen (O(1)), one deprotonated amide nitrogen atom (N(2)), one imino nitrogen atom (N(1)) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O(3)). The best-fit least-squares plane through the four basal and Cu atoms shows these atoms to be nearly coplanar. The O(1)-Cu(1)-N(2) angle of 179.39(15)° is nearly linear. The phenyl ring [C(1)-C(6)] and the ring of C(1), C(6), C(7), N(1), O(1), Cu(1) chelate ring are almost coplanar with a small dihedral angle of 5.5°. The coordination environment of Cu(2) is similar to that of Cu(1). The coordination of Cu and L forms a rigid metalloligand [CuL]- to bind Ba(II) ions. Ba(II) ion is ten-coordinated to five carboxylate oxygen (O(3), O(4), O(7), O(8), O(4)i; symmetry code i: 1-x, 1-y, 1-z), one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)ii; symmetry code ii: x, 1/2-y, 1/2+z) and four aqua ligands (O(1w), O(2w), O(3w), O(4w)). The Ba-O (water) distances range from 2.751(3) to 2.843(3) Å. The Ba-O (carboxylic and carbonyl oxygen) distances ranging from 2.758(3) to 3.059(3) Å are similar to the reported values . Two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]- and [Cu(2)L]-) coordinate to Ba(II) by two different modes: [Cu(1)L]- coordinate to Ba(II) ion through two bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms (O(3), O(4)) in μ 2-bridging manner. The Ba(1) and Cu(1) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(3) with Ba-Cu distance 4.65 Å, and Ba(1) and Ba(1A) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(4) and O(4A) and the Ba-Ba distance is 4.86 Å. [Cu(2)L]- coordinates to Ba(II) ions through two carboxylate oxygen (O(7), O(8)) in a bidentate manner and one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)). The dihedral angle between chelate ring planes of the two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]- and [Cu(2)L]-) is 29.2°. The nearest Cu⋯Cu distance is 3.56 Å between the two planes.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0020" view="all">Two barium cations link the four [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> metalloligands together via Ba–O bond to form a hexanuclear building block {[Cu(1)L][Cu(2)L]Ba(1)Ba(1A)[Cu(1A)L][Cu(2A)L]}. Each four adjacent building blocks are connected by Ba(II) and carbonyl oxygen atoms (O(6)), which form a 28-membered decanuclear metallocyclic ring (Ba6Cu4C4N4O10) (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>). The effective void size of the metallocyclic ring is 21.77<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6.45 Å. The symmetry-related Ba–O(6) bonds further join the adjacent building blocks together to give a extended 2D network structure along the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic>-plane (see ). The network structure is further stabilized through extensive hydrogen bondings involving carboxylate groups, carbonyl oxygen and coordinated water molecules. The entire structure is held networks together to form a 2D layer structure by van der Waals contact.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Two barium cations link the four [CuL]- metalloligands together via Ba-O bond to form a hexanuclear building block {[Cu(1)L][Cu(2)L]Ba(1)Ba(1A)[Cu(1A)L][Cu(2A)L]}. Each four adjacent building blocks are connected by Ba(II) and carbonyl oxygen atoms (O(6)), which form a 28-membered decanuclear metallocyclic ring (Ba6Cu4C4N4O10) (see  ). The effective void size of the metallocyclic ring is 21.77×6.45 Å. The symmetry-related Ba-O(6) bonds further join the adjacent building blocks together to give a extended 2D network structure along the bc-plane (see ). The network structure is further stabilized through extensive hydrogen bondings involving carboxylate groups, carbonyl oxygen and coordinated water molecules. The entire structure is held networks together to form a 2D layer structure by van der Waals contact.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0025" view="all">The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(COO) of the carboxylate group at 1609 and 1340 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The broad band at 1655 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> corresponds to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N). Medium band at 1297 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> probably corresponds to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(O–Ph).The strong broad band at 3442 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is attributed to H–O–H stretching vibrations of the water molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectrum of 1 shows ν(COO) of the carboxylate group at 1609 and 1340 cm-1, respectively. The broad band at 1655 cm-1 corresponds to ν(CN). Medium band at 1297 cm-1 probably corresponds to ν(O-Ph).The strong broad band at 3442 cm-1 is attributed to H-O-H stretching vibrations of the water molecule.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0030" view="all">The electronic spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was recorded in water and displays a strong absorption band at 344 nm is assigned to the imino n–π<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> transition. The d–d transition spectrum of the compound shows broad band centered at 563 nm, being suggestive of approximate square-planar geometry about Cu(II).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The electronic spectrum of 1 was recorded in water and displays a strong absorption band at 344 nm is assigned to the imino n-π* transition. The d-d transition spectrum of the compound shows broad band centered at 563 nm, being suggestive of approximate square-planar geometry about Cu(II).

elements.content: The effective magnetic moment at 300 K for complex 1 ̄ is 2.89 μ B , which is a little large than that of the spin-only value expected for the complex with no exchange interaction present (2.45 μ B ), indicating a weak interaction between two Cu(II) through the oxygen bridges. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements for the complex are underway and will be reported in a full paper.
elements.clean_text: The effective magnetic moment at 300 K for complex   1 ̄   is 2.89 μ  B , which is a little large than that of the spin-only value expected for the complex with no exchange interaction present (2.45 μ  B ), indicating a weak interaction between two Cu(II) through the oxygen bridges. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements for the complex are underway and will be reported in a full paper.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0040" view="all">In conclusion, this work describes the formation of a novel heterometallic network, which are assembled by metalloligands [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and the Ba(II) ions. The resulting polymer contains hexanuclear building blocks that result in what is the first example of a 2D extended hetreometallic network containing dipeptide Schiff-base complex. Further study on the synthesis and magnetic properties of this and related complexes is in progress.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, this work describes the formation of a novel heterometallic network, which are assembled by metalloligands [CuL]- and the Ba(II) ions. The resulting polymer contains hexanuclear building blocks that result in what is the first example of a 2D extended hetreometallic network containing dipeptide Schiff-base complex. Further study on the synthesis and magnetic properties of this and related complexes is in progress.

Copies of this information may be obtained free of charge from The Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336033; e-mail: <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="mailto:deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk" xlink:type="simple">deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk</ce:inter-ref> or www: <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk" xlink:type="simple">http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk</ce:inter-ref>).</ce:para>

Supplementary material

Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC No. 202244 for the compound. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ba: C, 34.69; H, 3.61; N, 6.74%. IR (KBr; cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3442s, 1655s, 1609s, 1340m, 1297m. ESI-MS (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>): 310.1, [CuL]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. Yield, 75%. Found: C, 34.58; H, 3.61; N, 6.66%.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>

</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Glycylglycine (10 mmol), 2-hydroxyacetophenone (10 mmol) and KOH (10 mmol) were dissolved and refluxed in MeOH/H2O (v:v=1:1) for half an hour. Cu(OAC)⋅H2O (10 mmol) was then added to the solution and the resulting solution was adjusted to the pH 9-10. At last BaCl2 ⋅2H2O (5 mmol) was added. The violet precipitate was obtained, which can be recrystallized from hot water (90 °C). The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature. After several days violet red crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction, were obtained. 2  Anal. Calc. for C24H30N4O12 Cu2Ba: C, 34.69; H, 3.61; N, 6.74%. IR (KBr; cm-1): 3442s, 1655s, 1609s, 1340m, 1297m. ESI-MS (m/z): 310.1, [CuL]-. Yield, 75%. Found: C, 34.58; H, 3.61; N, 6.66%.

cln_elements.content: The building block unit of the extended structure is shown in . 3 Crystallographic data of [Ba(H2O)4(CuL)2] are: C24H30N4O12Cu2Ba, Fw=830.95, monoclinic, space group P21 c, a=21.532(4) Å, b=7.266(1) Å, c=18.353(3) Å, β=91.57(1)°, V=2870.3(8) Å3, Z=4, D calc=1.923 gcm−3, crystals size: 0.15×0.15×0.20 mm3, 13627 reflections collected, of which 5018 (R int=0.0587 [I>2σ(I)]) were used in the refinement to give final R 1=0.0321 and wR 2=0.0618. Intensity data were collected on a Bruker CCD X-ray diffractomter using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method against F 2 using a SHELXTL software package. The coordination environment of the Cu(II) centers is approximately square-planar. The Schiff-base ligand is deprotonated, thus acting as a triple negatively charged quadridentate ONNO chelate. It coordinated to the Cu(II) atom via one phenolic oxygen (O(1)), one deprotonated amide nitrogen atom (N(2)), one imino nitrogen atom (N(1)) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O(3)). The best-fit least-squares plane through the four basal and Cu atoms shows these atoms to be nearly coplanar. The O(1)–Cu(1)–N(2) angle of 179.39(15)° is nearly linear. The phenyl ring [C(1)–C(6)] and the ring of C(1), C(6), C(7), N(1), O(1), Cu(1) chelate ring are almost coplanar with a small dihedral angle of 5.5°. The coordination environment of Cu(2) is similar to that of Cu(1). The coordination of Cu and L forms a rigid metalloligand [CuL]− to bind Ba(II) ions. Ba(II) ion is ten-coordinated to five carboxylate oxygen (O(3), O(4), O(7), O(8), O(4)i; symmetry code i: 1−x, 1−y, 1−z), one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)ii; symmetry code ii: x, 1/2−y, 1/2+z) and four aqua ligands (O(1w), O(2w), O(3w), O(4w)). The Ba–O (water) distances range from 2.751(3) to 2.843(3) Å. The Ba–O (carboxylic and carbonyl oxygen) distances ranging from 2.758(3) to 3.059(3) Å are similar to the reported values . Two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]− and [Cu(2)L]−) coordinate to Ba(II) by two different modes: [Cu(1)L]− coordinate to Ba(II) ion through two bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms (O(3), O(4)) in μ 2-bridging manner. The Ba(1) and Cu(1) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(3) with Ba–Cu distance 4.65 Å, and Ba(1) and Ba(1A) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(4) and O(4A) and the Ba–Ba distance is 4.86 Å. [Cu(2)L]− coordinates to Ba(II) ions through two carboxylate oxygen (O(7), O(8)) in a bidentate manner and one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)). The dihedral angle between chelate ring planes of the two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]− and [Cu(2)L]−) is 29.2°. The nearest Cu⋯Cu distance is 3.56 Å between the two planes.The effective magnetic moment at 300 K for complex 1 ̄ is 2.89 μ B , which is a little large than that of the spin-only value expected for the complex with no exchange interaction present (2.45 μ B ), indicating a weak interaction between two Cu(II) through the oxygen bridges. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements for the complex are underway and will be reported in a full paper.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The building block unit of the extended structure is shown in  . 3 Crystallographic data of [Ba(H2O)4(CuL)2] are: C24H30N4O12Cu2Ba, Fw=830.95, monoclinic, space group P21 c, a=21.532(4) Å, b=7.266(1) Å, c=18.353(3) Å, β=91.57(1)°, V=2870.3(8) Å3, Z=4, D calc=1.923 gcm-3, crystals size: 0.15×0.15×0.20 mm3, 13627 reflections collected, of which 5018 (R int=0.0587 [I>2σ(I)]) were used in the refinement to give final R 1=0.0321 and wR 2=0.0618. Intensity data were collected on a Bruker CCD X-ray diffractomter using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method against F 2 using a SHELXTL software package.   The coordination environment of the Cu(II) centers is approximately square-planar. The Schiff-base ligand is deprotonated, thus acting as a triple negatively charged quadridentate ONNO chelate. It coordinated to the Cu(II) atom via one phenolic oxygen (O(1)), one deprotonated amide nitrogen atom (N(2)), one imino nitrogen atom (N(1)) and one carboxylate oxygen atom (O(3)). The best-fit least-squares plane through the four basal and Cu atoms shows these atoms to be nearly coplanar. The O(1)-Cu(1)-N(2) angle of 179.39(15)° is nearly linear. The phenyl ring [C(1)-C(6)] and the ring of C(1), C(6), C(7), N(1), O(1), Cu(1) chelate ring are almost coplanar with a small dihedral angle of 5.5°. The coordination environment of Cu(2) is similar to that of Cu(1). The coordination of Cu and L forms a rigid metalloligand [CuL]- to bind Ba(II) ions. Ba(II) ion is ten-coordinated to five carboxylate oxygen (O(3), O(4), O(7), O(8), O(4)i; symmetry code i: 1-x, 1-y, 1-z), one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)ii; symmetry code ii: x, 1/2-y, 1/2+z) and four aqua ligands (O(1w), O(2w), O(3w), O(4w)). The Ba-O (water) distances range from 2.751(3) to 2.843(3) Å. The Ba-O (carboxylic and carbonyl oxygen) distances ranging from 2.758(3) to 3.059(3) Å are similar to the reported values . Two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]- and [Cu(2)L]-) coordinate to Ba(II) by two different modes: [Cu(1)L]- coordinate to Ba(II) ion through two bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms (O(3), O(4)) in μ 2-bridging manner. The Ba(1) and Cu(1) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(3) with Ba-Cu distance 4.65 Å, and Ba(1) and Ba(1A) are bridged by carboxylate oxygen O(4) and O(4A) and the Ba-Ba distance is 4.86 Å. [Cu(2)L]- coordinates to Ba(II) ions through two carboxylate oxygen (O(7), O(8)) in a bidentate manner and one carbonyl oxygen (O(6)). The dihedral angle between chelate ring planes of the two metalloligands ([Cu(1)L]- and [Cu(2)L]-) is 29.2°. The nearest Cu⋯Cu distance is 3.56 Å between the two planes.

The effective magnetic moment at 300 K for complex   1 ̄   is 2.89 μ  B , which is a little large than that of the spin-only value expected for the complex with no exchange interaction present (2.45 μ  B ), indicating a weak interaction between two Cu(II) through the oxygen bridges. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements for the complex are underway and will be reported in a full paper.

(symmetry code i: 1−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; ii: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1/2−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1/2+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; iii: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1/2−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −1/2+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>).</ce:simple-para>
